adjective.description: Having a high degree of heat or a high temperature.
examples: it was hot inside the hall

adjective.description: (of food) containing or consisting of pungent spices or peppers which produce a burning sensation when tasted.
examples: a very hot dish cooked with green chili
the idea had been nurtured in his hot imagination

adjective.description: Involving much activity, debate, or intense feeling.
examples: the environment has become a very hot issue
Tony is very hot on local history
he found my story simply too hot to handle
he hotted up the flask in Daisy's hand

phrases: Maggie, if you have the hots for Bianca, grow some balls and say so.
They knew we were friendly, a couple even knew I had the hots for her.
I've been hanging out with this fellow for about five months now, and although we're officially just friends, I've had the hots for him for months.
I saw that freak you have the hots for today, she said.
On the other hand, he might have the hots for you, but figure it couldn't be more than a one-night fling because of the distance, and maybe he's not into that.
origin: Old English hāt, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch heet and German heiss.
